bibl.title: Despatch from Aube, November 29, 1866
Despatches from United States Consuls in Gaboon, 1856-1888 T-466

text.body:
<div1 xml:lang="en" type="document"
<pb facs="20170615_114044"
Gaboon November 29th 1866
Gentlemen,
Your circular dated Nov. 26th 1866, having been handed to me today I hasten to inform you that I take into deep consideration the general opinion whuch have deetated it, but presuaded as I am that the decisions of the Admiral Commanding in Chief have been inspired as much be the guest interest which he take in countries of which the principles considerayion has been intrusted to him, as by a profound knowledge of the means of assuring theit industrial and commercial development it cannot enter into my mind to hesitate a moment in executing those decisions at the time appointed and to these full extent.
Nevertheless that period is far destiant many serious reasons leave me to think that this Admiral may arrive before January 1st of next year in which can you cannot doubt that I will <pb facs="20170615_114049" lay your Circular beforehand and he himself will consider the observations which it contains, but are those observations sufficently clearly expressed?
I do not think so I believe that a serious decision would put them in a better l*unclear at the same time it would dissapate certain event opp* economy certain impossesions without any real foundations which appear to me to be shown in the spirit of your letter.
Consequently I have the honor to request that you will call at the Government House on Monday most at 2 p.m. Assisted by the administrative myself by yhr most cannot reconcile your testimonials which are in point of fact those of the Circular with the strict executive of the orders of the Admiral Commanding in Chief perhaps I may be able to make you understand better both the *unclear and that *unclear*
<pb facs="20170615_114053" motives which have dictated his decision.
Finally it is not to be doubled that from this discussion I shall obtain a duper insight into your opinions and that will aid me much in acting as your inter- trader with the Admiral Commanding in Chief.
Be patient to accept Gentlemen, the assurance of any distinguished consideration,
Post Captain, officer of the legion of honor Commandiant of Gaboon.
Commandant Superior on interior Signed, Aube
